title: 110_s3571
content: The "Health Impact Assessments Act of 2008" or the "HIA Act of 2008" requires studies by the Government Accountability Office to identify best practices for assessing the planning and impact of land use, building design, and social policy on community health. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on best practices for using health impact assessments to promote health and reduce disparities through public policies. This study will also review the health consequences of Federal policies and programs. A report on the findings will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the health consequences of Federal policies and programs, exploring the use of health impact assessments for projects involving Federal funding or work. A report on the study's results will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The National Demonstration Program is established under Section 3. The Secretary will award a grant to an institution of higher education to provide technical assistance, grants, and training on health impact assessments for community planning and policy making. The grant will also support the development of necessary data and evidence for health impact assessments and administer a demonstration grant program. The Center awarded a grant to consult with national organizations for health impact assessments. The grant will be awarded to eligible entities for designing and administering health impact assessments at the state and local government levels. The grant awarded by the Center is for eligible entities to conduct health impact assessments at state and local government levels. The entities must consult with each other in carrying out the activities under the grant. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2009-2013. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will expand activities to promote health impact assessments for public health improvement and reducing disparities in land use, environment, and social policies. This includes developing guidance for assessing public participation and health effects, training efforts, and creating training tools. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding for fiscal years 2010-2013. The Act defines "built environment" as all buildings, spaces, and products created or modified by individuals, including homes, schools, workplaces, parks, transportation systems, and waste disposal sites. It also defines "health impact assessment" as procedures used to analyze the effects of policies, programs, or projects on population health and identify actions to manage those effects. The Act defines "health impact assessment" as analyzing the effects of policies, programs, or projects on population health and identifying actions to manage those effects. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
